text: No, no, definitely not. I picked up quite a judgy, self-righteous tone off the bat, but I finally realized this was not the book for me when she referred to one of her former clients as a "pub-crawling greaser." Sorry Gillian, you can keep your sense of superiority and I'll go hang out with the much more kind and relatable Gina Homolka.

First, who told Gillian it was ok to print in light pink letters on saturated hot pink pages? I get that color is fantastic, and eye catching, but this is retina-burning. Makes it an unpleasant read. I heard of Gillian from her BBC show "you are what you eat." I decided to pick up this book from the library, mainly to see if a few foods featured on her show had recipes in here. A lot of what is in this book is kind of obvious. Fruit, veggies, and organic are good for you, yes, we all know this. Some is interesting to consider, and then there's the rest. I appreciate her use of conventional chinese medicine (ie - the tongue diagnosis) and her pro-organic healthy style, but I think she's taken good ideas and gone over board. A few things in her book are in contradiction to what I've been told by my dietitian. Fine, different ideas are out there. Gillian has a very all-or-nothing attitude that I find a bit hard to work with. Hold on to your pants, I'm going to eat chocolate. I don't need to eat *all* the chocolate. But there's no little bit with her. There will be no chocolate, no alcohol, no caffeine, no red meat, no fat, no refined sugars, no flour, no, no no and NO. That's not so realistic in my world. I'm going to have dinner at friends house, and no I will not be asking to use their blender to juice my celery and cucumber stick. I'm going to work events and restaurants, and they may not be organic and raw foods. I'll deal. And you know what? I'll live. Again, I know first hand that when I eat well I feel good. (again, obvious) but life happens. And Gillian? I know PLENTY of people that eat your anti-christ diet and have strong interest in sex! So calm down on the sex drive already!

This book was pretty useless. The information was mostly either really basic ("Eat the good fats and throw out the bad. Good fats can be found in avocados, pumpkin seeds. . . Bad fats are saturated fats, as found in red meats and butter. They are very hard to digest, clog your arteries and led to illness and weight problems."), or it was very specific ("If you have small pimply bumps on the arm, take the following supplements daily: beta-carotene 15mg, B complex 50 g, and EFA 500 mcg."). She also advises food combining (not eating certain foods in the same meal as others, or taking care to have meals include foods from certain categories together), which, I gather from other sources, there is no scientific support for.Many of the pictures in the book are lovely close-ups of food, but there are also many pictures of the author in various food-related settings. I suppose that's necessary to feed the ego of someone who wrote a book like this after having her own TV show. (She does not address healthy ways to feed the ego.)

More of a 3.5, but it gets the nudge upward because I can think of a handful of people I'm going to recommend it to immediately.It was informative, light reading, and I am happy to have read it, but I had a few problems:1) There is very little to back up the claims made. Would have been a much more boring book with that info, but when making claims as large as some of those that are included, I like sources to be more clearly cited.2) Whoever came up with the design of the actual book ought to be shot. There are a handful of pages that are nearly unreadable due to the lack of contract between page and font color.I've already: - ordered a number of supplements- been drinking superfood fairly regularly - been drinking more herbal teas- ordered a skin brush- ordered a sprout kit.

i read the intro to this book-it scares me-i love to eat-and well i'm sure she's going to tell me a majority of what I love to eat is sooo bad for me!!!! i want to be healthier i really do but i dont want to give up food or exercise 1/2 my life away.....ha.finished this book and feeling really inspired to make parts of it into my daily life.tried the sweet potato shephards pie-a little bland will try w/ some more seasoning and maybe no pepers. :)

This is one of the best books on nutrition I have read in a long time. I found it on a road trip in a truck stop store. Gillian's expertise about foods chemistry, digestion and what to eat together is very helpful. Her knowledge of vitamins, minerals and herbs to help various conditions is also very good. This was not only an interesting read, but it will serve as a good reference book.

I skimmed this book, I did not read the whole thing. I requested it from the library because I liked the title and am generally interested in improving and varying my diet. It's quite a bit about macrobiotics--surprise! There is some interesting symptom/remedy information. It seems a bit drastic for most people to do everything recommended here. One interesting and easy-to-implement tip was chewing all your food well. "Your stomach doesn't have teeth." Well . . . yes! I like being reminded about all the healthy and natural things I could eat. Also interesting were the real life examples of people's diets that show how you can eat relatively few things yet be overweight. The author says eat more healthy things. I like being told to eat more! Pass the apples!
nice simple nutrition

I give this 4.5The author really sets out the case of why 'You are what you eat' . A very interesting read, she looks at the entire body and how when even the smallest part of the body eg nail is unhealth it is an indication of sum deficiancy in ones diet. I really gained alot from the book regarding food combination and its effect on digestion, when to drink water so as not to flood digestion. It was also good to be reminded why we need to take suppliments as our diets are insuffienct to supply all the vitamins, minierals that the body needs.My only gripe with the book is she advocates for eating almost on a constant basis, breakfast, snack, lunch, then snack, supper then snack. She did not delve much into the implication of what constant eating has on our hormones ie insulin and how we can end up being insulin resistance which can lead to weight gain. We need some periods of fast. Our bodies where not meant to be constantly focused only on the digestive process. What about autophagy? This aspect of health is not looked at.Otherwise this was a good read, will definatly be referring back to certain sections of the book.

Few people know or remember that Gillian McKeith had a television show, as I recall, also called "You Are What You Eat", which I sporadically watched while it lasted due to the entertainment factor. During the duration of the half an hour or so the episodes lasted, Gillian would visit the homes of families with awful eating habits, investigate their fridges, make angry comments about how offensive she finds all the Chinese take-out leftovers, Coca-Cola, and/or hot pockets their fridge holds, and then send them off to poop in a large, clear container before taking this container and waving it around and saying, "See? SEE HOW UNHEALTHY YOUR STOOL IS?" (Due to this habit, she is known internationally as--I'm not making this up--the Awful Poo Lady.)Those families were eating vegetable casserole for the rest of their lives. I guarantee it.Her book isn't nearly as menacing as her television show. In it, Ms. McKeith tells you simply what kind of food is bad and what is good, and tells you what kind of food can help you improve brainpower or muscles or various other things. (Apparently raw sauerkraut is good for your sex drive. I never knew that before. Did anyone?) She does it comprehensively and obviously knows what she's doing, and manages to hold the reader's interest, despite the fact that it is, you know, a cookbook. Four stars.

I liked the way this book was printed and presented. It's very colorful and glossy, and it's divided into really small segments, so you can easily pick it up and read a few pages and complete a whole topic. It covers interesting things such as looking at physical problems and figuring out what you may be deficient on -- for instance cracks on the fingertips or tongue. It's right up my alley to use the nutrients in foods to heal and to eliminate the bad things to help fix health problems. What's not up my alley is eating crap, not exercising and then seeking out medicines to mask problems. This book focuses on improving health through wholesome foods, but it's not intimidating. It's informative and simple. She offers a simple 1-day cleanse that involves a lot of fluids -- water and tea and fresh veggie and fruit juice -- along with green smoothies, miso soup and fresh veggies. Most "cleanses" are long and intimidating. This one seems so much more doable. The book offers a few recipe ideas in the back and some examples of eating for a week. It's not entirely opposed to any entire food group -- something I'm always interested in knowing before purchasing a nutrition/diet book. It pushes raw veggies first and foremost and some animal proteins if carefully chosen. It urges going light on wheat but definitely eating whole grains -- millet, quinoa, etc.

I picked this book up in an airport on a whim...I didn't realize it was connected to the television program that I had caught once or twice. This book is laid out really well, in short topics, graphics, or lists making the information really easy to (dare I say) digest. I have been reading a lot about food lately and while I know better than to believe everything I read, I feel that this book is full of useful lessons for someone looking to really understand what to fuel the body with. I won't be incorporating every lesson this book has to offer, I have certainly taken away some advice that I plan to turn into healthy eating habits. This is not a diet plan or a limiting food guide....it's more of a wake up call on what we are actually putting into our bodies, some thing I feel like many of us feel we are too busy to do. (Although it does offer a 7 day meal plan with recipes to support)I've insisted that we have a copy of this book for our staff lunch room! Money & time well spent!
It's an inspiring book for healthy eating with lovely photos, don't agree with all of the suggested tips
Although I'm not ready to do everything this book suggests, there are some great tips. I'm starting with chewing my food throughly!
This is just common sense stuff, eat your veggies, no processed foods etc. Though pretty to look at but I didn't learn anything new.
My version was published in 2004. Absolutely loved the TV series and thoroughly enjoyed reading this.
Lists, recipes, ideas, simple solutions, basic explanations. A good review of what many of us already know, but in a really useful format.
basic informationi liked the part of superfood

One of the best informative and colorful books on nutrition that I have read in quite some time!I watched Gillian McKeith on her BBC television show many years ago; she really knows her stuff!If you are interested in a no-nonsense nutritional guide that will help you on a healthy journey, this is it!

Horrible book. Full of pseudoscience and diagnosis with no foundation whatsoever. Prescribe lots os vitamins and supplements. Demonize milk, coffee and other food and also tells lies about nutritional facts for beans, breads and others.
If this was a work of fiction, it would've got 5 stars for entertainment. However, for factual content, this was very poor.
Interesting but very far fetched for every day living.
She really wants you to eat Quinoa!

Graphically written for a child-like read, this book is in the ‚Äúscolding nanny‚Äù format not unusual in Britain where academic knowledge is also a licence to talk down to readers as if they are idiots. This means that books with good content (like this one) are hard to put up with the intellectual arrogance.Once you get past the self promotions, ridiculous tv-sensational examples, the insane page colours, and some truly horrific writing, there is good content to evaluate nutritional health.Hard to blame some poor advice (the sun does not rise and set on Nettle tea) which is culturally better accepted by the UK audience. The questions to evaluate health are actually well thought out. The discussion of stress quite good. She pushes the boundaries of tools to address issues in a fantastic way. She also gives diagnostic tools (evaluate your tongue üëÖ) that is a welcome add on. Read and pass on to someone.

McKeith has a bad reputation in some circles as being the notorious "poo lady" on a British reality show. As in, I guess she inspects people's feces and then berates them for being such fat, unhealthy slobs. Well, that sounds entertaining (not).Still, I actually liked this book. The main take-home message: eat lots of fresh, unprocessed stuff, especially veggies, and avoid the "bad nasties" like soda and junk food. But it's presented in a fun, inspirational way. This book actually has helped me to improve my diet and reduce some bad habits, so I do recommend it...with a couple reservations.One is to do your own research about the supplements she recommends. I am not against wisely using some supplements, for example I find that taking valerian before bedtime actually works better than some prescriptions I've tried. I relax and fall asleep...no side effects! Likewise, a cup of peppermint tea after a heavy meal calms my stomach down, so no need for an antacid. On the other hand, people can get into trouble if they're not smart, like what happened with ephedra. Some people took huge amounts of that herb, in mixed "energy" or "weight loss" pills, when that is not even the appropriate use of the herb to start with. Because of things like that, herbs which are helpful in some circumstances get banned, and everything is tarnished with the same brush.I don't recall McKeith giving any particularly bad advice (based on my study of herbalism), but it's always a good idea to do some research before taking anything. (As possible sources for your research, I recommend Andrew Weil or Rosemary Gladstar, two authors whose advice has never led me astray.)The only real quibble I have with this book is that she mentions getting colonics at one point. It's not a major part of the book, but I am really tired of faddish and unnecessary crap (no pun intended) creeping into every other book in this market. (Well, she is the "poo" lady...)

I rented this book hoping to get some recipes from the show, there are a few recipes, but it is more like a guide on how to do what the people in the show do. I want to try the sweet potato shepherds pie & the chickpea burgers - after I try them I will post a review of the recipes.If you like her show on BBCAmerica (it sure is transfixing! Like a super-natural makeover) And want some tips on how to do that, read this bookThe book has lots of recommendations for natural healing - please check with your doctor or Rph before trying things like st johns wort or valerian etc. - these are drugs that really ought to be regulated by the FDA.I tried the veggie bean patties - hmm ... thank goodness I asked Bob to get some tomato soup from bread co., as the only suitable way to eat them was crumbled up into the soup. It tasted good that way, but not what I was looking for. I was hoping for a gluten free veggie pattie that steph could eat as a 'burger'. These were very crumbly and quite tasteless (I used coriander, cumin, and salt to season the mixture before baking). The mixture before baking was way too wet, and I wondered if the conversion from metric to standard measurements ruined the balance. I have not tried the shepherds pie yet.

As a health and wellness professional myself, I would NEVER hand this book to someone to read.While you do find nuggets of helpful information hidden among the old school diet industry myths like drinking water with lemon first thing in the morning, you can‚Äôt even receive it because of the judgemental and condemning voice of the author.She refers to her own clientele as being a ‚Äúpub crawling greaser,‚Äù and another as having ‚Äúhideous cellulite.‚Äù She also continuously claims that if you sit. exactly follow her plan you will end up disease ridden and then dead.Unbelievably unprofessional.Maybe it‚Äôs meant to be tough love? Her tone and even her ‚Äúmy way or death‚Äù approach wouldn‚Äôt even be so bad if she actually had scientific backing to any of her claims. If you‚Äôve studied nutrition yourself you‚Äôll find that she doesn‚Äôt.Side note for anyone who hasn‚Äôt studied nutrition themself: if anyone claims a one size fits all approach to health as the only way, stop reading.

This book is incredibly informative. It's not a step by step guide to health, like many fad diet books are, but instead it explains why the foods we eat do what they do. A great overview if you are tyring to change your overall health, but don't know where to start. EDIT: So, a few years have gone by and I notice that I consult this book basically never. I've kept some of the things in it in mind, but after seeing the TV show, and reading more and learning and just basically going through life ... well, I have a little less faith in the claims made here. In conclusion, I still think this book is a decent place to start if you are in absolute terrible health and eat like crap and you want to make a change. If you are already fairly active, eat alright and aren't in bad health, then there are other books out there that may be better suited for your needs.

Rubbish - a needless complicated plan that she insists is simple. Tons of assertions without providing any evidence except the occasional anecdote. And totally shaming language throughout. There is one quiz where the scores are divided into 5 sections. If you score 51-100 pts, your section is titled "You are a big mess. You are not okay" - and its not even the worst score you can get. 101-151 pts is "You flunk big time!" Dr. Gillian - you flunk big time.Update: Just found this online:"One of those angry nerds took her down this week. A regular from my website badscience.net - I can barely contain my pride - took McKeith to the Advertising Standards Authority, complaining about her using the title "doctor" on the basis of a qualification gained by correspondence course from a non-accredited American college."Ms Gillian - you flunk big time!

I loved this show when it was on BBC and I'd been wanting to read this book for a long time. Probably the first half was about what I expected, with McKeith discussing what fruits and veg are best for certain health problems, looking at the tongue and the dreaded bowels (her obsession with feces seems like a fetish). I have started on Vitamin E, per her suggestion that this will rid me of red, scaly hands.The last several chapters sort of lost me as she highly recommends algae (not gonna happen) and meditation, even including some chants. Which seems so un-Gillian McKeith to me. Where's the angry woman who stomps around the grocery store telling people they're fat and spotty?Anyway, there is enough food info here to have me consulting it multiple times.

Some really good info on supplements to take/foods to eat for various conditions and most of her nutritional advice makes sense. I'm not completely convinced about the food combining though. Thought that pretty much went out in the 70s. I'll have to start paying attention to how I feel after eating certain foods together to see if that holds water for me. There are a few recipes in this book to get you started, but I also picked up an inexpensive copy of the accompanying cookbook. I've seen the show on BBCA and am interested in trying a few of her recipes - millet mash, chickpea burgers, among others. I'm sure at least a few will make it into my regular rotation.

Like any book, you have to take all the advice in it with a grain of salt. Know what works best for you. Take the good and leave the rest. I do not agree with a lot of the book. But there are some interesting things in it. For example she advocates taking a lot of herbal supplements and drinking smoothies daily for detox cleanses. Dr. Caldwell B. Esselstyn explained (on his webpage) that fruit smoothies don't stay in the mouth long enough to get coated with digestive enzymes. So it is better to eat whole fruit rather than blend it up. Page 40,44, and 45 were interesting, but other than that there was not much new information for me to glean.

Gives a basic overview how to impove your health in general.It goes beyond nutrician and mentions skin brushing and other techniques as well. I liked the questionaires thaat you are supposed to take, andthe resulting action plans for you individual needs. The book is nicely illustrated. the only negative point is that it doesn¬¥t give very clear nutricional advice. For example the book promotes a vegan lifestyle but gives recipes with meat and dairy.Nevertheless I found the book still usefull as it gives advice how to change your diet, dependign what illness/deficencies you have. I also liked the chapter on how to detect potential illnesses from examining your tongue, skin, hair, eyes.

Great information but pretty overwhelming. I think it would be a good reference book to brush up on nutrition when I find myself slipping and feeling sluggish but it's a pretty involved plan to dive into headfirst.If you have a particular problem, like PMS or headaches, it would be a great book to reference on how to feel better by eating/drinking certain things.I'm not a whole-hearted convert to the Gillian way of life but I'm certainly a believer in her philosophy of good food=feeling good.

I don't know if I buy into all that is said in this book, but it has made me rethink what I eat and helped me see that I am probably tired (not feeling healthy, etc.) all the time because I'm not eating enough variety. Having the same exact thing for breakfast, lunch, and slight variations in dinner is not going to do it as far as getting all the vitamins, etc. I need. She also talks about how foods eaten together affect you (she believes fruit should always be eaten alone - not with grains, vegetables, or meat).

Good in the respect that I learned some more herbs/supplements to take for certain health issues I have. Also some good points about what foods should not be eaten together. How digestion works, what digests the fastest and how drinking with meals influences that. Particularly interesting was the section on body indicators of health. The tongue is used as a guide by many alternative health practitioners and everything listed was something I have. Same for the sections of the body with acne! Very accurate.

SO, she's a little on the extreme side, but a lot of what she says seems right on. Of course, I'm just comparing what she says to what everyone else says... but several things are prety well confirmed. Others aren't, but that doesn't mean they aren't true. Wow, My first few sentences show exceptional writing skills... ha. ANyways, basically, I like a lot of what she has to say, but someone reading about how they need to brush their skin for the first time might think she's a little off her rocker. :)

I think this book is pretty good, however I wish it was a bit less hip and trendy with it's aesthetically pleasing pages and gave you more reasons as to why, say, if you have dry skin you should do X. Not that everything is always explainable, and not saying that some of the things don't work... on the contrary, I think she has a lot of good advice. I just wish it was presented a bit more systematically.

This book is good for a detox and to change the way you eat, but it may be a little drastic for most people. It does give some good information on why we suffer certain ailments and how you can correct it with food. It talks about food combining, good sweets, things to avoid, and what foods are good for certain parts of the body. It also gives some food lists from each food group and recipes. Overall a good book for detox, weight loss and healthier lifestyle.

Promoting a holistic 80/20 raw foods almost vegetarian/vegan-ish food plan, McKeith writes on some unique habit changes for living a well-rounded and healthy life. The last half of the book intrigued me most with topics on food combining, ever day natural "detox" (not a fan of this word, but it is what it is....) recommendations, and a sample meal 7 day mostly raw foods meal plan. If you can get past the first half of generic just "eat clean" then a handful of tips are provided in due time.

No coffee, no alcohol, no dairy, need to eat sea vegetables (?!?)- not the diet for me. But as w/any healthy eating book, there are always SOME tips I can incorporate in my life; eating raw veggies daily (salad), chew food thoroughly til liquified, drink a cup of warm water w/lemon in the morning & evening. I might also try the dry-skin brushing!

Talk about taking a cold hard look at what you eat! This book woke me up and really provides a different way of thinking about your health. She does a great job of showing what foods contribute to bad health and how to get on track. Some of it may seem a bit extreme, but believe me, when you feel like crap like I did, you'll do just about anything.

Again, I think if you really care about your health, you should buy or at least check out the book. I knew most of the info in there already, but it's so handy to have it compiled together. It is colorful, informative and easy to read. Discusses various health topics. If it tells you anything, even my husband likes reading it.

splendidly easy to read, and obtain information!i love this book, and if you love the concepts of eating raw, and eating for optimum health, you'll love it too! :)learn what foods to eat according to your symptomslearn to eat as much as you want, and be thin and happy!contains many radical and incredible methods for improving health, and conquering stress and the American eating epidemic!

If you want to feel awful about what you currently eat and completely discouraged by what you "should" eat then this is the book for you. Ok really this book is probably really a great guide for eating and I believe a lot of it (definitely not all) but as for practical application for real people (like moms with small children) it just doesn't help.

We would all benefit from eating better, and this book gives you some good reasons why and some insight into how we should go about it. The only drawback is that it takes lots of time to prepare fresh food, so the busy among us will find it hard to fulfill this plan daily. I have watched the BBC TV show, and it is sad & funny and always has a 'lighter' ending. ha ha.

Very nice and interesting book for anyone interested in nutrition and diet. It's very easy to read and it's a really nice starting book in those areas. Some recipes, very nice and yummy, and full of details about nutrition, diet and health. Fantastic book, might not agree with everything, but it doesn't stop the book from being a fantastic book.

This is an outstanding nutrition book. Ms. McKeith is a very informed nutritionist and even if you consider yourself a health or nutrition expert, you can benefit a lot from this book. She has great remedies for many common ailments. I adopted a lot of her principles and have seen tremendous improvement.

This was an informative book on nutrition. It was pretty basic in discussing the benefits of eating raw fruits and vegetables. It talked about using supplements to make up for what is lacking in our diets and could be causing illness or problems within our bodies. It was certainly a glimpse into how poorly humans as a whole eat and the bad things we are doing to our bodies because of that.

I love Gillian McKeith's show of the same name and I wanted to see what Gillian suggests are the healthiest foods to eat for various addictions, ailments etc. I have allergies and I am hoping that by changing my diet it will lessen the symptoms. It is very well written and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to be a little healthier.

I couldn't finish this without being sent into clinical depression. I believe everything she wrote but apparently our society is really off course, it is overwhelming. Most of the food suggestions were not only completely foreign to me, but I also had no idea how to cook them. She did offer recipes and a plan, but I still wanted to cry. This method is apparently way too advanced for me.

There is nothing what I am using out of these knowledges I read. Hope they works for others. But I am not a single person, so there is no way how could I push my man and kids to eat and drink as this book suggests. Maybe, when I will become very old and kids will live their own lives, I can try to re-read the book and try some things. But for now, I 'll be looking for another book... Sorry...

I really enjoyed reading the tips (some closely, others skimmed) in this book, though I thought the layout and design were overbearing and distracting at times. A lot of the nutritional tips seem good, though some seem "different" (over-the-top or just different? not sure), so I doubt I'll try them all, but it's good to have some things to work on.

Lots of great information about how what you eat affects your health. Sometimes we think we know exactly what it takes to eat well and be healthy, but I did find some interesting facts about food and supplements that aren't so obvious. I will be heading to the health food store to look up some of the supplements McKeith recommended.

This was a very informative and interesting read. However, it bothered me that she felt or advised in her week plan for food to only eat fruits and vegetables and drink them in liquid form. It's very unlinkely that people would give up rice, pasta and evergthing else they eat. I'm also sure you can fit that into your diet without being unhealthy.

This is a fantastic book that serves as a reference for me and my family. She has a lot of simple lifestyle changes that can make a huge impact on your health and ultimately overall happiness. When you feel good, you do good. Most people in this world walk around blind to just how miserable they actually are. I recommend this book to anyone and everyone.

This is the second time I've read this book. Dr. Gillian can get some seriously crazy foods to help detox and get people healthy. When I first read it, I just couldn't fathom some of her suggestions. Now after my last bout with my ulcer I'm willing to try almost anything to avoid that from happening again.

Some of the reviews were negative because the author did not cite evidence/studies to support what she was writing. I did not find this to take away from my enjoyment of this book. Her information was not new, controversial or unbelievable. I didn't need proof. I did, however, thoroughly enjoy the pictures. They were visually stunning.

This is a great resource book. It's broken into easy to read sections with lots of visuals. It can be read all at once but is just as effective when read in small chunks. I refer back to this book often when I or anyone in my family is having a health issue. The recommended foods and supplements always seem to be spot on.

I will take away some good habits from this, like food combining. And it was a good reminder to drink my herbal teas. I also really enjoyed her reminders on positivity toward your body. But there some thoughts in this book I found a little outdated and disagreed with. I'm a big proponent of primal, and won't adopt her habits on meat and certain fats.

This book has a great detox day guide as well as teaching you natural ways to fix problems your body is having. I have read it a couple times and often times look back for specific info from it. Great source of support and information for someone trying to eat healthier.

I'm hooked on the BBC America show (very inspiring!)and wanted to read the book by the nutritionist that is behind all of it. The book is very colorful, but I had a lot of trouble with the layout. Too magazine-y and jump cut-y, like an MTV program...Good info though once you suss it out.

Okay, I really just love the show on BBC mostly because she slaps people's fat guts and calls them lardy lards in her British accent. But according to the information in the book, my tongue is trying to tell me that my spleen is weak.

Really liked this book... another one on nutrition and how to eat better. It also went on to talk about different things showing up on your body meaning that you were deficient in a specific nutrient... Loved this book.

If you're interested in real nutrition and are tired of diet hype and not knowing who to believe - check this book out. You Are What You Eat is colorful, easy to read, and a wealth of information. I checked this out from the library, but will definitely be purchasing it for my reference library.

This book makes me feel like I've gained special access into a rainbow room filled with foods I've known and others I've never heard of, with lots and lots of reasons why they're the ticket to feeling and looking better for life. This will be a resource that I keep in my kitchen for a long time.

Based on her BBC show "You Are What You Eat". She's a tough cookie, but the diet is not. The best part of this book is how she "reads" body signs to determine nutrition deficiency.(bags under the eyes, cracks on the tongue, dry skin, etc)

I loved this book. It gave me so much insight as to how and what I was eating. Though, I am certain I could not strictly follow her plan I have taken many recommendations and added them to my diet and lifestyle.

Gillian has great suggestions and I learned many things that I had never heard before even w/ the numerous nutrition classes I had taken. I like the food combining thoughts she has - and they have made a difference at our house!

This book discusses how specific foods can either cause problems or heal our bodies. Probably not hugely diet-altering for me but definitely learned so foods to avoid or seek out. Overall, quite a fascinating read.

Basically a proponent for adding more raw or barely cooked foods into our diets. She recommends more supplements than I agree with. Interesting...again lots of nutritional information. Might be good as a reference for those interested in foods and their specific nutritional values.

Quite an interesting book about how food can help you to feel better.I always wonder if Dr. McKeith is a real doctor, but if you don't think about that, she makes sense most of the times, even though sometimes she seems to be taking the piss.

Apparently Gillian McKeith can be pretty extreme in real life, but the book version of her is not bad. The book is filled with quite a lot of good information about the foods that we eat, and how your body reacts to them (both good and bad.)

Read it in 2 days (fast for me). Loved it. I seriously devoured every word. I'm excited to implement a lot of the stuff it talked about. I think my family and I will benefit from what I learned. Everyone needs to read this book!

I went through a faze where I thought for sure I wanted to be a nutritionist. That, and I hate subjecting my body to chemicals. This book was awesome. Taught me what I was doing to my body when I ate certain things. Taught me how to be healthy without shitty dieting.

I know she gets a lot of flak but this book is good. However she came by the contents they are definitely sound ideas for the most. I dip into this book as and when I have to thank her for introducing me to mung & adzuki beans yum yum

It was a fun read! Lots of facts and lots of pictures! It was not the best book that I have read on the subject of health, but it is a great one to get you started if you are interested in the topic of what is in our food.

Loved the book and all the reasons why "you are what you eat". Garbage in, garbage out - as the saying goes. You don't run a car engine on water, so why put bad fuel in our bodies and expect peak performance? This makes you think twice about what goes down the throat...

This book added a new dimension to my life. I'm more aware of food combining and how it benefits my health. I am taking the correct supplements & seeing improvements. It is a very colorful, informative book that I recommend to everyone!

It had a lot of interesting info, but I found I didn't like the way the book was set up. It lists symptoms or complaints and what to do to for them or foods to eat that may help. Anyhow, it didn't jive with me.

I recommend it. It's a colorful, fun book about health. You'll want to switch from unhealthy to healthy after reading it. It explains why you should avoid unhealthy food and how to change your diet with simple tricks
My only problem with this book is that I've never heard of half of the things she tells us to eat. Although, that's my fault and not hers.
After reading this book, pasta and donuts freak me out.
Whoa! I leared so much from this book. An amazing guide to nutrition and what we should be eating. Very eye-opening.
It's part common sense, part interesting...I especially like the parts where she talks about what certain foods do for you & tells you how to read your body (skin, tongue, etc.)
borrowed from my Pilates instructor.
All books about diet really make me confuse!
a good read, if not to make you more aware of what you put in your body (don't worry, we all bow a little every now and then..)
It is a book filled with information about how to improve the conditions of every part of your body. I follow the intructions inside and they work! I feel much healthier now!
started me on my path to health. Recipes are bland though. I think she's afraid of spices!
What a wealth of information about what we put in our bodies.
Such a wealth of information. Ignited my interest in learning to use food as medicine. Beautiful images of food, many helpful facts and remedies. People interested in healthy food, check this out.
a very healtful approach to changing your life and your eating habits. a very useful nutrition book and reference book as well.
ongoing work in progress/reference material.... can't follow word for word but gives some good pointers
this book was awesome. then as i did further research it seems that the author is a fake, a sham! it was very informative. i also recommend skinny bitch series.
This book changed my health and my life. A few of her ideas may seem extreme, so take it for what it is worth.
This book is enlightening. Every page I would come out with an "oh!"... I learned a lot. I would buy a copy for all of my friends if I have the $$!
McKeith = diet the right, healthy way.... not really a diet more of a lifestyle change. Trust me it is hard at first, but you will feel amazing after 3 weeks.
This is an amazing book that got me all excited--again--about nutrition. I'm even growing my own sprouts and wheatgrass! It also has a great gentle detox that Jed and I have done.
I became interested in this book after watching her TV show on the BBC.
If your looking for a good, green, healthy lifestyle solution, this is excellent. Most of Gillian's dietary advice is just good, common sense.
I watch her TV show then read her book. It's a real eye opener.
Great information but for me this plan is hard to follow. I have pulled from it a few great recipes.
The truth about all diets/healthy eating: Eat REAL food! I like the book but wish it didn't focus so heavily on supplements.
Great, practical advice on nutrition. My husband and I go through cycles where we pick this up and read it again and again.
What food to eat to improve exzema and asthma
who knew your tongue was a key part of tracking your health? interesting book - lots of valuable tips and unique insight to your health and the food you eat.
This book is so full of crap I couldn't get it out of my house and back to the library quick enough.
Really eye-opening. Highly recommended to anyone who wants to get healthy.
c2004: obsessed with colons
"Dr" McKeith has some very interesting points, but her self righteousness gets on my nerves.
This book was pretty basic, so you won't get much out of it if you have a basic understanding of nutrition.
I'm sure some people would love this book and her eating plan. Me, not so much.
I tried one of the detox plans out of this and to be honest,it made me feel like c**p.
I would have given this a four but the colour-scheme of the book is just awful. She's not for everybody, but I found information in here that was helpful to me.
Using the diet for fatloss and reverse my husband cardiovascular condition after his heart attack coz infark myocard...
Loved this book. Although I may not be ready to implement everything the book suggests (yet), it is full of great information. A must read for everyone.
Reader friendly. The format is perfect for conveying a lot of information in a "digestible" way.
I loved this book, it had great tips, some things I knew and some I didn't.I could hardly put this book down, it was very interesting!
I didn't enjoy this. It seems like an unnecessarily complicated plan. I watched snippets of the show which I thought was interesting but really disappointed in the book.
Informative but claims seem a little unfounded at times.
Great book, easy to understand.
I really liked the format and organization of this book and that it focuses on nutrition rather than trying to be a cookbook. I'm going to try the cleanse soon as it looks very doable.
Some interesting information but no allowance for real life or the odd treat. Very much all or nothing. Too many lists of vitamin supplements when I wanted to know about the foods.
Love it, love it, LOVE IT! She makes so much sense. She makes a point to eat some 'live' foods with as many meals as poss, such as sprouts and greens.
Wow! Learned a lot about food and how it interacts with our bodies. Feel much better changing just the few things that I have can't wait to change more.
Re-read this as a reminder to look after myself. She's fairly extreme in her recommendations, but a reminder of just how bad sweets and chocolate are for the body was just what I need right now.
Another approach to health eating and the whole foods, real foods movement. Good easily digestible info...
Most of her food "hacks" correspond with Ayurveda. Hence the 5 stars. Again, this plan could be made a way of life and not a fad diet one would discontinue in a week.
so elaborated knowledge about food..."either make food your medicine, or medicine your food"
Such a great, informative, and extensive book. It does a great job at explaining why and what the benefits/risks are of foods.
The book was okay, but her view point was very extreme.
I feel like this book is going to help me break out of my pattern of fad diets.
Interesting, but no one really has time to do what she suggest to make a lot of the time.
Just like the BBC show, makes nutrition fun! No, seriously!
Good book to own as a reference.
Very, very interesting!
Excellent guidline book for following a healthy lifestyle.
ok
